19: What‚Äôs clear to me from my jaunts along this former line is that it it isn‚Äôt a candidate for restoration, no matter how hard campaigners fight. It‚Äôs simply too far gone for this to be viable. I‚Äôll leave you with a reminder of the timetable back in its glory days. ENDS https://t.co/IaTcDAAab5

18: here is the site of the former Hopworthy Farm level crossing, scene of a fatal collision between farm equipment and a train in 1950 which killed three people. I was told by the farmer‚Äôs sister, who remembers the line closure in 1966, that this sign is original. https://t.co/BJuyupqEn4
17: these pictures show the view looking eastwards towards Derriton, where the formation is still obvious https://t.co/9xIstLH7xQ
16: These pictures are looking west towards the bridge from further away. The formation ran immediately alongside the hedge on the south side https://t.co/Kd0jk62QBH

15: Believe it or not, this is the formation of the railway line. The farmer told me it took him five weeks of continuous work using a digger to remove the embankment and fill the cutting, reversing the process the navvies would have done by hand over 100 years earlier https://t.co/bJDpqZyClW

14: The mystery was solved when I spoke to the current farmer, who inherited the farm from his Dad, who had bought the formation for the princely sum of ¬£200 after the line closed. The son decided to level off his fields, where there had been both an embankment and a cutting. https://t.co/lv6cwc6rTa

13: But the mystery for me was what happened to the formation immediately east of here. This picture was taken from the adjacent field. Look closely and you can just make out the wooden fencing on the bridge, and you can see the embankment just stops dead where the field starts https://t.co/bgPJuYDHWB
12: these pictures shown the view looking east and west from the bridge. The formation has been carefully maintained along this section at least https://t.co/2lAteSVsy5

11. Returning to Upper Hopworthy, this bridge still stands at the end of the farmer‚Äôs land where we have been staying this week. It‚Äôs had recent attention to its pointing and to remove trees threatening the structure, presumably by contractors working for Highways England https://t.co/Yy6O01it5q
10: this house now stands where the former shunt neck used to be. At least it has an appropriate name! https://t.co/QNhfYd602i

9: Moving to the line‚Äôs terminus at Bude, there is now little evidence of where the station once stood. Rather odd, since the town and its museum proudly & rightly commemorates the Bude Canal, and considering how it clamoured so hard to get the railway extended in the first place https://t.co/Pbphb2DAVS

8: looking the other way along the formation from the overbridge at Whitstone & Bridgerule station, you can see what 55 years of unobstructed nature can do. The line closed in October 1966 https://t.co/26HKUO3Lri
7: the station had a passing loop, signal box (of course!) plus sidings and even a goods shed, not in a particularly ‚Äògood‚Äô condition today https://t.co/Z1KeKx9Ppo

6: skipping past Hopworthy for a moment, the only intermediate station on the extension was at Whitstone & Bridgerule, two nearby villages one each in Cornwall and Devon. My pictures show the view from the station as was towards the bridge from where I took the current one https://t.co/96DfEPvBmB

5: here is the view along the formation as you go west from Derriton viaduct - this is the best maintained bit of formation on the whole of the route, because it is an official part of the National Cycle Network https://t.co/OhCS0v4ewj

4: just west of the town there is the impressive Derriton viaduct, happily in much better condition and now a part of the National Cycle Network. Look carefully and you can see the date 1898 underneath where I‚Äôm standing https://t.co/o5DOwt1Qgy

3. These pictures show the formation immediately to the east of Holsworthy station, leading up to the entrance to Holsworthy viaduct, which is now closed off as an unsafe structure https://t.co/LVrb10AnjC

2. First up, Holsworthy station, once a thriving terminus of the route (until extended to Bude in 1898). It had a good shed, loco shed, sidings and all. Now it‚Äôs a Waitrose supermarket https://t.co/koF2OrJ8Ii

33. ...And so to my summary: this is a good and concise set of proposals, but for which there is much unresolved detail required before we can tell if it will work as intended. But there is clearly no going back, so we must wish it a fair wind and send it on with our best wishes.

32. ...And finally, the proposed structure seems to make open access players unwelcome, and will serve to limit incremental access opportunities. Why would GBR, designing its integrated timetables, want competitors stealing its market. Another area of conflict looms here...

31. ...Nearly there now: I anticipate a serious risk of GBR being captured by a production and engineering focus, rather than being genuinely customer-led. It will be heavily dependant on leadership, culture, & keeping a healthy distance from central gov't to make it work well...

30. It's imperative that GBR's cost & staffing budget includes sufficient headroom to develop an effective "informed client" role, like TfL provides for London Overground & DLR. Without a cadre of experts, paid at market rates, concession specs will strangle the model at birth...

29. ...The incentivisation proposals for concessionaires are undeveloped or unclear. This could lead to ineffective use of the private sector's flair and entrepreneurialism. If all is needed is 'follow the dots' style operators, then it might as well all be taken back in house...

28. ...The proposed financial framework appears to leave a mechanism for DfT & HMT to 'call the tune'. I guess this is inevitable given the amount of public money lubricating the system, but the sooner rail's licence to operate can be regained and the ties loosened, the better...

27. ...The flexi-seasons proposal is overly mean and inadequately flexible; once the new breed of part time commuter hits the ticket office many of them will be disappointed. This will probably need another go at to improve it in due course...

26. ...for Operators, and its brim full with common sense ideas and new initiatives to help the railway get better. Indeed, you might ask (and I do) why hasn't DfT got on with a lot of this stuff some time ago?
That's the positives; next, some drawbacks as I see them...

25. ...Plus points: Creation of 'fat controller' organisation, removal of DfT from day to day involvement in railway management and design/letting of operating contracts, abolition of RDG, creation of single national brand and ticketing/info channel, reduced barriers to entry...

24. There is clearly much to be welcomed here, but also a some concerns about the missing detail, and about how some of this stuff will be made to work better in the future when it hasn't in the past. Nevertheless, I can distil some key strong points from it and these follow...
23. I've read the report and summarised its key points in this thread so you don't have to bother. You can thank me later! But what are my own conclusions? Keep reading...

22. The report's conclusion includes a commitment to establish a Rail Transformation Programme and an Advisory Group to the SoS, and name checks both Andrew Haines and Keith Williams with involvement in this. It also promises to push through some quick wins.

21. Chapter 8 is about empowering rail's people, and is no doubt deliberately a bit thin on how the staff cost base is to be tackled. But there is a commitment to a sustained programme of skills, training and leadership development, including a nod to Connected Leaders (good!).

20. ...and there's a commitment to a worthy open-by-default approach to data, a simplification of funding mechanisms for R&D and innovation, and a supportive nod to Project SPEED. I received a faint whiff of green-washing though.

19. Chapter 7 is about accelerating innovation and modernisation. It includes a long overdue commitment to electrification, and Environment Plan and long term approach to climate resilience, all of which seems a bit Motherhood & Apple Pie stuff without any real detail,...

18. ..., encouragement to work locally with SMEs, and a revolution in Wi-Fi connectivity are all promised, but there is little supporting detail on how these lofty ideals will be achieved that's different to what's happened up to now.

17. Chapter 6 is entitled "unleashing the private sector's potential", but is made of rather thin gruel. There's to be a statutory duty to promote freight, & gov't guidance on freight priorities for each CP. Incentives on operators to collaborate and innovate with 3rd parties...

16. ...What's really great is to see all this really important stuff for passengers spelt out in clear strategy ready to be implemented. Let's hope this is followed through effectively. On the downside the flexi-seasons proposal is underwhelming for many new part time commuters.

15. ...Delay Repay at 15', improved on board info such as loading data, a national accessibility strategy + matching statutory obligation, and BIG DRUM ROLL PLEASE more comfy seats and improved passenger on-board amenity in general! What's not to like here? ...

14. ...for integration with buses (journey planning + integrated ticketing - but perhaps more difficult than suggested?), simplification of fares, protection of turn-up-and-go,  customer service coming out from behind the ticket office window, more space for bikes, national...

13. Chapter 5, a new deal for passengers, has a great diagnosis box and lots of meat in it. Most of it gets big ticks from me, including a national extension of PAYG, a national rollout of digital ticketing via smartphone, the new website and App, acting as a portal...

12. ...However, open access approach looks confused: whilst notionally it's seen as a possible for expansion, it's clearly not a core part of the strategy. You can see that it really doesn't fit well with the new model: GBR is likely to be as keen on OA as DfT has been until now.

11. On the plus side, bidding should become simpler, with less delivery risk on timetables; and barriers to entry look to be lowered which should encourage new players to bring fresh approaches and more innovation...

10. ...It's also unclear how operators will have any teeth against an under-performing infrastructure partner, given that the latter team is also directly employed by the concession lessor. The devil is really in the detail here, and none of it is spelt out as yet...

9. Chapter 4 is all about replacing franchising, and its diagnosis box can't really be argued with. It's unclear though how the new Passenger Service Contracts will incentivise bidders to cut costs effectively, rather than baking in high costs as for the last 25 years...

8. ...and last, but by no means least, a strategic approach to track access planning coupled with legislative reform of the current access rights system. All in all, chapter 3 reads pretty well as a set of aspirations for improvements in this area

7. But there are a number of big ticks also in this chapter: partnership working to be encouraged; integrated station management; enhanced role for @TransportFocus; safety roles of RSSB, RAIB and BTP retained (very sensible: current roles well established and working well) ...

6. ...Its "single national network" pits UK gov't against TS and TfW and their aspirations to control their own infrastructure. The intention to retain UK control of Scottish rail infrastructure is made explicit. Conflict looms here...

5. ...creates 5 operational divisions (based on current NR Regions) with "customer-focused leadership teams" & "integrated local teams" for track and train "in partnership with operators". (?) But no detail on how this might work, and accepts does not fit TfN area well...

4. Chapter 3, integrating the railways is all good stuff: creates the guiding mind many have called for, abolishes RDG, recreates a national brand & a single retailing point, retains ORR as independent arbiter of funding needs & efficiency + its appeals role for all operators...

3. Chapter 2, our commitment to rail, contains clear, laudable objectives. But also contains a warning that operating expenditure other than on infrastructure will not benefit from 5-year plan guarantees; this means Treasury & DfT will continue to exert control behind the scenes
2. The 1st chapter, on the recent history of our railways since privatisation, has nothing much that is worth challenging: it's lucid, concise and very frank, so gets an enormous tick from me

1. I've now examined the entire White Paper. My conclusion: it's very much better than I had expected, although some bits are worked up in much more detail than others. It's also heavy on aspiration, and light on bankable mechanisms to achieve some of its objectives. Analysis...
